data.event: 1 AD First year in Christian calendar, which is presently used in unison with the Gregorian calendar almost everywhere in the world.
Herod Archelaus deposed by Augustus

event.title: Samaria, Judea, Idumea under Roman admin

data.event: Samaria, Judea and Idumea annexed as Iudaea Province under direct Roman administration, capital at Caesarea, Quirinius became Legate (Governor) of Syria, conducted first Roman tax census of Iudaea, opposed by Zealots (Acts 5:37)
Brief period of peace, relatively free of revolt and bloodshed in Iudaea & Galilee

event.title: Hillel the Elder dies, Shammai rises

data.event: Pharisee leader Hillel the Elder dies, rise of Shammai
Tiberius, Roman Emperor

event.title: Caiaphas, High Priest of Herod's Temple

data.event: Caiaphas, appointed High Priest of Herod's Temple by Prefect Valerius Gratus, deposed by Syrian Legate Vitellius

event.title: Jews, Jewish Proselytes, Astrologers expelled from Rome

data.event: Jews, Jewish Proselytes, Astrologers, expelled from Rome (Suetonius,Lives of the Twelve Caesars, Tiberius 36, Loeb Classics)
Pontius Pilate, Prefect of Iudaea

John the Baptist, relative of Jesus (Luke 1:36), a Nazirite (Luke 1:15), began ministry in "15th year of Tiberius" (Luke 3:1-2), baptized Jesus (Mark 1:4-11), arrested and beheaded by Herod Antipas (Luke 3:19-20,JA18.5.2)

Jesus' ministry, Sermon on the Mount, appointed Twelve Apostles, disturbance at Herod's Temple (Mark 11:15-19, John 2:13-17), crucified on Friday (Mark 15:42, John 19:42), Nisan 14th (John 19:14, Mark 14:2, Gospel of Peter) or Nisan 15th (Synoptic Gospels), (7Apr30, 3Apr33, 30Mar36, possible Fri-14-Nisan dates, -Meier), entombed by Pharisees Joseph of Arimathea and Nicodemus of the Sanhedrin, resurrected by God, appeared to Paul of Tarsus (1Cor 15:3-9), Simon Peter (Luke 24:34), Mary Magdalene (Mark 16:9, John 20:10-18), and others, Great Commission, Ascension, prophecy of Second Coming, see also Chronology of Jesus

Jerusalem church founded, first Christian church, about 120 Jews and Jewish Proselytes, (Acts 1:15), Pentacost, Ananias and Sapphira incident, Pharisee Gamaliel spoke in defense of the Apostles (Acts 5:34), Saint Stephen stoned (Persecution of Christians) and the church dispersed (Acts 7:54-8:8), Simon Magus baptized in Samaria (Acts 8:9-24), Philip the Evangelist baptized an Ethiopian eunuch (Acts 8:26-40)
Simon Peter baptized Roman Centurion Cornelius, considered first Gentile convert to Christianity (Acts 10), Antioch church founded, it was there that the term Christian was first used (Acts 11:26)

event.title: St. James the Great executed by Herod Agrippa

data.event: Saint James the Great, brother of John, executed by Herod Agrippa I (Acts 12:1-3)
Paul's 1st mission, (Acts 13:1-14:27), with Barnabas, to Cyprus, Pisidian Antioch, Iconium, Lystra and Derbe (there they were called "gods ... in human form"), then return to Syrian Antioch

"Since the Jews constantly made disturbances at the instigation of Chrestus [1], he <Claudius> expelled them from Rome." (Suetonius,Lives of the Twelve Caesars,Claudius XXV.4,Loeb Classics) (referenced in Acts 18:2)
Passover riot in Jerusalem, 20-30,000 killed (JA20.5.3,JW2.12.1)
Council of Jerusalem, "Apostolic Decree" (Acts 15:1-35)
52? Saint Thomas Christians of India

Paul's 3rd mission, (Acts 18:23-21:26), to Galatia, Phrygia, Corinth, Ephesus, Macedonia, Greece, Jerusalem, there James the Just challenged him about rumor of teaching antinomianism (Acts 21:21), he addressed a crowd in their language (most likely Aramaic) (Acts 22), Romans, 1 Corinthians, 2 Corinthians, Philippians written?
"Egyptian Prophet" and 30,000 unarmed Jews doing The Exodus reenactment massacred by Procurator Antonius Felix (Acts 21:38, JW2.261, JA20.169)
Paul arrested, accused of being a revolutionary, "ringleader of the sect of the Nazarenes", teaching resurrection of the dead, imprisoned in Caesarea (Acts 23-26)
Paul shipwrecked on Malta, there he was called a god (Acts 28:6)

Paul in Rome: greeted by many "brothers", three days later called together the Jewish leaders, who hadn't received any word from Judea about him, but were curious about "this sect", which everywhere is spoken against; he tried to convince them from the "Law and Prophets", with partial success, said the Gentiles would listen and spent two years proclaiming the "Lord Jesus Christ" (Acts 28:15-31); Epistle to Philemon written?

event.title: James the Just stoned to death

data.event: James the Just stoned to death for law transgression by High Priest Ananus ben Artanus, popular opinion against act results in Ananus being deposed by new procurator Clodius Albinus (JA20.9.1)
Simeon, 2nd Bishop of Jerusalem, crucified under Trajan
Glastonbury Abbey founded according to tradition, but date disputed

event.title: Great Fire of Rome, Nero blamed, persecuted

data.event: 64-68 after July 18 Great Fire of Rome, Nero blamed and persecuted the Christians, earliest mention of Christians, by that name, in Rome, see also Tacitus on Jesus, Paul beheaded? (Col1:24, Eph3:13, 2Tm4:6-8, 1Clem5:5-7), Peter crucified upside down? (Jn21:18,1Pt5:13,Origen), "...a vast multitude, were convicted, not so much of the crime of incendiarism as of hatred of the human race. And in their deaths they were made the subjects of sport; for they were wrapped in the hides of wild beasts and torn to pieces by dogs, or nailed to crosses, or set on fire, and when day declined, were burned to serve for nocturnal lights." (Annals (Tacitus) XV.44)
Q document, a hypothetical Greek text thought by many critical scholars to have been used in writing of Matthew and Luke
Great Jewish Revolt: destruction of Herod's Temple, Qumran community destroyed, site of Dead Sea Scrolls found in 1947

event.title: Ignatius of Antioch fed to lions in Rome

data.event: Ignatius, third Bishop of Antioch, fed to the lions in Rome, advocated the Bishop, rejected Sabbath?, his letters were subjected to heavy Christian forgery especially 4th century (Apostolic Fathers)
Gospel of Mark, written in Rome?, by Peter's interpreter? (1 Peter 5:13), original ending apparently lost, endings added c.400, see Mark 16
Signs Gospel written, hypothetical Greek text used in Gospel of John to prove Jesus is the Messiah
Pauline Epistles

70-200? Didache; Other Gospels: Unknown Berlin Gospel, Gospel of Peter, Gospel of Thomas, Oxyrhynchus Gospels, Egerton Gospel, Fayyum Fragment, Dialogue of the Saviour; Jewish Christian Gospels: Gospel of the Ebionites, Gospel of the Hebrews, Gospel of the Nazarenes
Gospel of Matthew, based on Mark and Q, most popular in Early Christianity
Gospel of Luke, based on Mark and Q, also Acts of the Apostles by same author
Clement I, Bishop of Rome, wrote Letter of the Romans to the Corinthians (Apostolic Fathers)
90? Council of Jamnia of Judaism (disputed)
1 Peter
Testimonium Flavianum, disputed section of Jewish Antiquities by Josephus in Aramaic, translated to Koine Greek
Gospel of John and Epistles of John
Book of Revelation written, by John (son of Zebedee) and/or a disciple of his
Epistle of Barnabas (Apostolic Fathers)
Epistle of James
Epistle of Jude written, probably by doubting relative of Jesus (Mark 6,3), rejected by some early Christians due to its reference to apocryphal Book of Enoch (v14), Epistle to the Hebrews written
100-150? Apocryphon of James, Gospel of Mary Magdalene, Gospel of James, Infancy Gospel of Thomas, Secret Gospel of Mark (Complete Gospels, published by Jesus Seminar)

event.title: Expositions of Sayings of the Lord

data.event: Papias, bishop of Hierapolis, wrote: "Expositions of the Sayings of the Lord", lost, widely quoted (Apostolic Fathers)
110-160? Polycarp, bishop of Smyrna, Letter to the Philippians, (Apostolic Fathers)
125(+/-5)? 2 Peter written, not accepted into canon until early 400s, drew upon Epistle of Jude, "catholic" epistle, Pastoral Epistles written
Rylands Library Papyrus P52, oldest extant NT fragment, p.1935, parts of Jn18:31-33,37-38

"Christian Apologists" writings against Roman religion: Justin Martyr, Athenagoras, Apology of Aristides, Theophilus of Antioch, Tatian, Quadratus, Melito of Sardis, Apollinaris Claudius, Felix Marcus Minucius, Arnobius, Epistle to Diognetus
Bar Kokhba's revolt: final Jewish revolt, Judea and Jerusalem erased from maps, all of southern Syria renamed Palestine (coined by Herodotus)

142-144? Marcion of Sinope, bishop according to Catholic Encyclopedia, went to Rome, possibly to buy the bishropic of Rome, upon rejection formed his own church in Rome, later called Marcionism, rejected Old Testament, decreed canon of one Gospel, one Apostolicon (10 Letters of Paul) and one Antithesis[2] which contrasted the Old Testament with the New Testament, cited Western text-type
"Western Revisor" adds/subtracts from original Acts to produce Western version which is 10% larger and found in Papyrus P29,38,48 and Codex Bezae (D)

event.title: Valentinius lost election for Bishop of Rome

data.event: Valentinius, most famous Christian Gnostic, according to Tertullian narrowly lost election for Bishop of Rome
Shepherd of Hermas, written in Rome (Apostolic Fathers)
Montanus, claimed to be the Paraclete ("Counselor") of John 14:16
Martyrdom of Polycarp (Apostolic Fathers)
Dionysius[3], bishop of Corinth, claimed Christians were changing and faking his own letters just as [he knew] they had changed the Gospels (EH4.23.12;Ante-Nicene Fathers,v.8)
Tatian produces "Diatessaron" (Harmony) by blending 4 "Western" text-type Gospels into 1
Symmachus the Ebionite, new Greek translation of Hebrew Bible
Hegesippus
Irenaeus, Bishop of Lyon, combated heresies, cited "Western" Gospel text-type (Ante-Nicene Fathers)
Muratorian fragment, 1st extant canon for New Testament after Marcion?, written in Rome by Hippolytus?, excludes Hebrews, James, 1-2 Peter, 3 John; includes Wisdom of Solomon, Apocalypse of Peter
Saint Apollonius, used the term catholic in reference to 1 John
Saint Demetrius, bishop of Alexandria, condemned Origen
Pope Victor I, 1st Latin Pope, excommunicated Eastern churches that continued to observe Easter on Nisan 14 Quartodeciman
Polycrates, bishop of Ephesus (Ante-Nicene Fathers)
Caius[4], presbyter of Rome, wrote "Dialogue against Proclus" in Ante-Nicene Fathers, rejected Revelation, said to be by Gnostic Cerinthus

Papyrus 46: 2nd Chester Beatty, Alexandrian text-type; Papyrus 66: 2nd Bodmer, John, 1956, "Alexandrian/Western" text-types; Papyrus 75: Bodmer 14-15, Luke & John, earliest extant Luke, ~Vaticanus; 200? Papyrus 32: J. Rylands Library: Titus 1:11-15;2:3-8; Papyrus 64 (+67): Mt3:9,15; 5:20-22,25-28; 26:7-8,10,14-15,22-23,31-33
Sextus Julius Africanus

Antipope Natalius[5], rival bishop of Rome, according to Eusebius's EH5.28.8-12, quoting the Little Labyrinth of Hippolytus, after being "scourged all night by the holy angels", covered in ash, dressed in sackcloth, and "after some difficulty", tearfully submitted to Pope Zephyrinus
Antipope Hippolytus, Logos sect?

event.title: Bishop of Carthage claims Christians forge his letters

data.event: Cyprian, Bishop of Carthage, cited "Western" NT text-type, claimed Christians were freely forging his letters to discredit him (Ante-Nicene Fathers)

Clement of Alexandria, cited "Alexandrian" NT text-type & Secret Gospel of Mark & Gospel of the Egyptians; wrote: "Exhortations to the Greeks"; "Rich Man's Salutation"; "To the Newly Baptized"; (Ante-Nicene Fathers)
Codex Tchacos, manuscript containing a copy of the Gospel of Judas has been written.

Tertullian, sometimes called "father of the Latin Church" because he coined trinitas, tres Personae, una Substantia, Vetus Testamentum, Novum Testamentum, convert to Montanism, cited "Western" Gospel text-type (Ante-Nicene Fathers)
Papyrus 45: 1st Chester Beatty, Gospels (Caesarean text-type), Acts (Alexandrian test-type)
Maximinus Thrax, emperor of Rome, ends Christian schism in Rome by deporting Pope Pontian and Antipope Hippolytus to Sardinia where they soon die
Dionysius, Patriarch of Alexandria see also List of Patriarchs of Alexandria
Apostolic Constitutions, Liturgy of St James, Apostles' Creed, Clementine literature
Letters of Methodius, Pistis Sophia, Porphyry Tyrius, Commodianus (Ante-Nicene Fathers)

Papyrus 72: Bodmer 5-11+, pub. 1959, "Alexandrian" text-type: Nativity of Mary; 3Cor; Odes of Solomon 11; Jude 1-25; Melito's Homily on Passover; Hymn fragment; Apology of Phileas; Ps33,34; 1Pt1:1-5:14; 2Pt1:1-3:18

Origen, Jesus and God one substance, adopted at First Council of Nicaea in 325, compiled Hexapla; cites Alexandrian, Caesarean text-type; Eusebius claimed Origen castrated himself for Christ due to Mt19:12 (EH6.8.1-3)
Synods of Carthage
Antipope Novatian, decreed no forgiveness for sins after baptism

event.title: Schism over rebaptizing heretics and apostates

data.event: Pope Stephen I; major schism over rebaptizing heretics and apostates

event.title: Roman emperor executes Christian Bishops, Elders, Deacons

data.event: "Valerian's Massacre", Roman emperor executes all Christian Bishops, Elders, and Deacons
Synods of Antioch, condemned Paul of Samosata, Bishop of Antioch, founder of Adoptionism (Jesus was human until Holy Spirit descended at his baptism), also condemned term homoousios adopted at Nicaea
Gregory Thaumaturgus (Ante-Nicene Fathers)

event.title: Anthony the Great begins monastic movement

data.event: Anthony begins monastic movement
Papyrus 47: 3rd Chester Beatty, ~Sinaiticus, Rev9:10-11:3,5-16:15,17-17:2
Mani (prophet), crucified, founder of Manichaean Christian sect in Persia
Theonas, bishop of Alexandria (Ante-Nicene Fathers)
St Pachomius, founder of Christian monasticism
Pope Marcellinus, offered pagan sacrifices for Diocletian
Armenia, first to adopt Christianity as state religion
Diocletian's Massacre of Christians
Saint George, patron saint of England, and other states
304? Victorinus, bishop of Pettau
306 Synod of Elvira, prohibited relations between Christians and Jews
Maxentius deports Pope Eusebius and Antipope Heraclius[6] to Sicily
Lucian of Antioch, founded School of Antioch, martyred
Vision of Constantine, while gazing into the sun he saw a cross with the words by this sign conquer, see also Labarum, Constantine was later called the 13th Apostle

event.title: Christianity state religion of Kingdom of Aksum

data.event: The Kingdom of Aksum(Modern Ethiopia) declares Christianity as the official state Religion
Edict of Milan, Constantine and Licinius end persecution, establish toleration of Christianity
Pope Miltiades, given Lateran Palace as residence by Constantine, excommunicated Donatus Magnus for requiring rebaptism of apostates

event.title: Council of Arles against Donatist schism

data.event: Council of Arles, called by Constantine against Donatist schism
Eusebius, bishop of Caesarea, church historian, cited Caesarean text-type, wrote Ecclesiastical History in 325
Mirian III of Georgia adopts Christianity as state religion
Lactantius
Constantine decreed Sunday as state "day of rest" (CJ3.12.2), see also Sol Invictus

event.title: First Council of Nicaea to unify Christology

data.event: First Council of Nicaea, called by Constantine to unify Christology, called 1st great Christian council by Jerome, 1st ecumenical, Original Nicene Creed, rejected by Nontrinitarianism, Arius, Theonas, Secundus, Eusebius of Nicomedia, Theognis excommunicated, addressed Easter controversies, passed 20 Canon laws
Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem
Athanasius, bishop of Alexandria, first cite of modern 27 book New Testament canon
Old Church of the Holy Apostles, dedicated by Constantine
Old Saint Peter's Basilica dedicated by Constantine, located over the traditional burial site of Saint Peter the Apostle in Rome on Vatican Hill
Capital of Roman Empire moved from Rome to Constantinople (New Rome)
Council in Jerusalem, reversed Nicaea's condemnation of Arius, consecrated Jerusalem Church of the Holy Sepulchre
Council of Sardica
Julius Firmicus Maternus
Codex Sinaiticus(S), Codex Vaticanus(B): earliest Christian Bibles, Alexandrian text-type
350? Ulfilas, Arian, apostle to the Goths, translated Greek NT to Gothic
Comma Johanneum 1Jn5:7b-8a(KJV)
Aëtius, Arian, "Syntagmation": "God is agennetos (unbegotten)", (Anomoean)
School of Nisibis founded

event.title: 2nd Council of Sirmium condemned Council of Nicaea

data.event: 2nd Council of Sirmium, Anomoean, condemned Council of Nicaea
Hilary, bishop of Poitiers
Antipope Felix II, Arian, supported by Constantius II
Council of Rimini, Dated Creed (Acacians)
Council of Laodicea, canon 29 decreed anathema for Christians who rest on the Sabbath, disputed canon 60 named 26 NT books (excluded Revelation)
Antipope Ursicinus, rival to Pope Damasus I
Epiphanius, bishop of Salamis, wrote Panarion against heresies
Basil the Great, Bishop of Caesarea
Doctrine of Addai at Edessa proclaims 17 book NT canon using Diatessaron (instead of the 4 Gospels) + Acts + 15 Pauline Epistles (inc. 3 Corinthians) Syriac Orthodox Church
Gregory, Bishop Of Nyssa
Ephrem the Syrian, cited "Western" Acts text-type
Ambrose, bishop & governor of Milan
Ausonius, Christian governor of Gaul
Gregory Nazianzus, Bishop of Constantinople
First Council of Constantinople, 2nd ecumenical, Jesus had true human soul, Nicene Creed of 381
Council of Rome, held by Pope Damasus I, disputed
Frumentius, Apostle of Ethiopia
Priscillian, first heretic to be executed?

event.title: Nicene Christianity declared state religion by Theodosius the Great

data.event: Feb 27, Nicene Christianity declared state religion by Theodosius the Great
Apollinaris, bishop of Laodicea, believed Jesus had human body but divine spirit
Augustine, bishop of Hippo, considered the founder of formalized Christian theology (Nicene and Post-Nicene Fathers)
Saint Ninian evangelizes Picts in Scotland
398-404 John Chrysostom Patriarch of Constantinople, see also List of Patriarchs of Constantinople, (Nicene and Post-Nicene Fathers)
Ethiopic Bible: in Ge'ez, 81 books, standard Ethiopian Orthodox Bible
Peshitta Bible in Syriac (Aramaic), Syr(p), OT + 22 NT, excludes: 2Pt, 2-3Jn, Jude, Rev; standard Syriac Orthodox Church Bible
Armenian Bible, translated by Saint Mesrob, standard Armenian Orthodox Bible
Cyril, bishop of Alexandria, expelled Jews, killed Hypatia with oyster shells, coined Hypostatic union
Antipope Eulalius rival to Pope Boniface I
St. Jerome, Vulgate translations, Latin scholar, cited expanded ending in Mark after Mark 16:8, Pericope of the Adultress addition to John (John 7:53-8:11) (Nicene and Post-Nicene Fathers)
Theodoret, bishop of Cyrrhus, noted Tatian's Diatesseron in heavy use
Council of Ephesus, 3rd ecumenical, repudiated Nestorianism, decreed Mary the Mother of God, forbid any changes to Nicene Creed of 381, rejected by Assyrian Church of the East

event.title: St. Patrick begins mission in Ireland

data.event: St Patrick begins mission in Ireland

event.title: Pope Leo I first pope, stopped Attila the Hun

data.event: Pope Leo the Great, sometimes considered the first pope, stopped Attila the Hun at Rome, issued Tome in support of Hypostatic Union, approved Council of Chalcedon but rejected canons in 453
Council of Toledo added Filioque clause to Nicene Creed of 381
Robber Council of Ephesus, Monophysite: Jesus was divine but not human
Codex Alexandrinus(A): Alexandrian text-type; Codex Bezae(D): Greek/Latin Gospels + Acts; Codex Washingtonianus(W): Greek Gospels; both of Western text-type
Aramaic Targums, Old Testament in Aramaic
Socrates Scholasticus, Sozomen, early Church historians
Council of Chalcedon, 4th ecumenical, declared Jesus is a Hypostatic Union: both human and divine in one, Chalcedonian Creed, rejected by Oriental Orthodoxy
Eutyches of Constantinople, Monophysite
Prosper of Aquitaine
September 4th, Fall of Rome
Acacian Schism, over Henoticon divides Eastern (Greek) and Western (Latin) churches
Armenian Orthodox split from East (Greek) and West (Latin) churches
May 13 Vicar of Christ decreed a title of Bishop of Rome by Pope Gelasius I
Clovis I, King of the Franks, baptized
Antipope Laurentius, rival of Pope Symmachus
Antipope Laurentius, rival of Pope Symmachus
Incense introduced in Christian church service, first plans of Vatican
Boethius, Roman Christian philosopher, wrote: "Theological Tractates", Consolation of Philosophy; (Loeb Classics) (Latin)
Dionysius Exiguus sets Christian calendar (a.d.) & Jesus' birth @ 23 Dec 1AD
Fabius Planciades Fulgentius
Antipope Dioscorus, possibly a legitimate Pope
Rule of St Benedict, St. Benedict founds the Benedictines
Unusual climate changes recorded

537-555 Pope Vigilius, involved in death of Pope Silverius, conspired with Justinian and Theodora, on April 11, 548 issued Judicatum supporting Justinian's anti-Hypostatic Union, excommunicated by bishops of Carthage in 550
Plague of Justinian
Justinian condemns Origen, disastrous earthquakes hit the world
Justinian condemns the Three Chapters of Theodore of Mopsuestia (d.428) and other writings of Hypostatic Union Christology of Council of Chalcedon
St. David converts Wales.
crucifix introduced
Second Council of Constantinople, 5th ecumenical, called by Justinian
Pope Pelagius I, selected by Justinian, endorsed Judicatum
Columba goes to Scotland to evangelize Picts, establishes monastery at Iona
Cassiodorus
Third Council of Toledo, Reccared and the Visigoths convert from Arianism to Catholicism
Pope Gregory the Great, whom many consider the greatest pope ever, reforms church structure and administration and establishes Gregorian Chant, Seven deadly sins ...
Theodelinda, Queen of the Lombards, began gradual conversion from Arianism to Catholicism

event.title: St. Augustine of Canterbury evangelises the Jutes

data.event: St. Augustine of Canterbury sent by Pope Gregory to evangelise the Jutes
Evagrius Scholasticus Church historian
St Paul's Cathedral in London
607 Pope Boniface III, first Bishop of Rome to be called "Pope" and "Universal Bishop" by decree of Emperor Phocas
Pantheon, Rome renamed Church of Santa Maria Rotonda
Bobbio monastery in northern Italy

event.title: Abbey of St. Gall in Switzerland

data.event: Abbey of St. Gall in Switzerland

event.title: Khosrau II of Persia took Holy Cross of Christ

data.event: Khosrau II of Persia conquered Damascus, Jerusalem, took Holy Cross of Christ
Battle of Badr, considered beginning of Islamic Empire
Paulinus of York comes to convert Northumbria
Babai the Great, pillar of Assyrian Church of the East, died

event.title: Cross of Christ and Jerusalem recovered from Islam

data.event: Battle of Mut'ah, Heraclius recovered Cross of Christ and Jerusalem from Islam till 638
Eorpwald of East Anglia baptized under influence of Edwin of Northumbria

event.title: Umar conquers Syria, Egypt, Armenia, Persia

data.event: Umar, 2nd Sunni Islam Caliph, capital at Damascus, conquered Syria in 635, defeated Heraclius at Battle of Yarmuk in 636, conquered Egypt and Armenia in 639, Persia in 642
Cynegils of Wessex baptized by Bishop Birinus
Library of Alexandria, "The Center of Western Culture," with 300,000 ancient papyrus scrolls, is completely destroyed.
Synod of Whitby unites Celtic Christianity of British Isles with Roman Catholicism
Third Council of Constantinople, 6th ecumenical, against Monothelites, condemned Pope Honorius I, Patriarch Sergius I of Constantinople, Heraclius' Ecthesis
Wilfrid converts Sussex
Dome of the Rock built
Old English Bible translations
Orthodox Quinisext Council, convoked by Justinian II, approved Canons of the Apostles of Apostolic Constitutions, Clerical celibacy, rejected by Pope Constantine
Fall of Carthage
Islamic conquest of Iberia
Second Arab siege of Constantinople
Reconquista, Iberian Peninsula retaken by Christendom
Saint Boniface, an Englishman, given commission by Pope Gregory II to evangelize the Germans
Disentis Abbey of Switzerland
First Iconoclasm, Byzantine Emperor Leo III bans Christian icons, Pope Gregory II excommunicates him
English Church History written by Bede

event.title: Tower added to St. Peter's Basilica

data.event: Tower added to St Peter's Basilica at the front of the atrium
Donation of Constantine, granted Western Roman Empire to the Pope, later proved a forgery
Donation of Pepin recognizes Papal States
Nestorian Stele
Daqin Pagoda
Jesus Sutras
Christianity in China
Second Council of Nicaea, 7th ecumenical, ends first Iconoclasm

event.title: Beginning of Viking raids on Christendom

data.event: Sacking of the monastery of Lindisfarne marks the beginning of Viking raids on Christendom.

event.title: Charlemagne crowned first Holy Roman Emperor

data.event: King Charlemagne of the Franks is crowned first Holy Roman Emperor of the West by Pope Leo III.

event.title: Ansgar evangelises North Germany, Denmark, Sweden

data.event: Ansgar, Archbishop of Bremen, "Apostle of the North", began evangelisation of North Germany, Denmark, Sweden
Antipope Anastasius, Louis II, Holy Roman Emperor appointed him over Pope Benedict III but popular pressure caused withdrawal

event.title: St. Cyril and St. Methodius evangelise Slavic peoples

data.event: Saint Cyril and Saint Methodius sent by the Patriarch of Constantinople to evangelise the Slavic peoples. They translate the Bible into Slavonic.

event.title: Catholic 4th Council of Constantinople condemned Patriarch Photius

data.event: Catholic Fourth Council of Constantinople, condemned Patriarch Photius, rejected by Orthodox

event.title: Orthodox 4th Council of Constantinople restored Photius

data.event: Orthodox Fourth Council of Constantinople, restored Photius, condemned Pope Nicholas I and Filioque, rejected by Catholics
Cadaver Synod, Pope Stephen VI conducts trial against dead Pope Formosus, public uprising against Stephen led to his imprisonment and strangulation
Abbey of Cluny, Benedictine monastery in France
Einsiedeln Abbey of Switzerland
Mieszko I duke of Poland baptised, Poland becomes a Christian country.
Antipope Boniface VII, murdered Pope John XIV, alleged to have murdered Pope Benedict VI in 974
Baptism of Kievan Rus'
Antipope John XVI, deposed by Pope Gregory V and his cousin Holy Roman Emperor Otto III
Much speculation and fear regarding the approach of the millennium
Antipope Gregory VI, removed by Henry II, Holy Roman Emperor
Battle of Stiklestad, considered victory of Christianity over Norwegian Paganism
Sigfrid of Sweden, Benedictine evangelist
Council of Sutri, Pope Silvester III exiled, Pope Gregory VI admitted to buying the papacy and resigned, Pope Benedict IX resigned, council appointed Pope Clement II
East-West Schism split between Eastern (Orthodox Christianity) and Western (Roman Catholic) churches formalized
Antipope Benedict X, defeated in war with Pope Nicholas II and Normans
Antipope Honorius II rival of Pope Alexander II
Westminster Abbey consecrated
Pope Gregory VII, Investiture Controversy with Henry IV, Holy Roman Emperor, proponent of Clerical celibacy, opponent of simony, concubinage, Antipope Clement III
Stanislaus of Szczepanów, patron saint of Poland
Engelberg Abbey of Switzerland
Anselm, Archbishop of Canterbury, wrote Cur Deus Homo (Why God Became Man), a landmark exploration of the Atonement
10 Crusades, first called by Pope Urban II at Council of Clermont against Islamic empire to reconquer the Holy Land for Christendom
Foundation of the reforming monastery of Citeaux, leads to the growth of the Cistercian order.
Antipope Theodoric and Antipope Adalbert deposed by Pope Paschal II
Knights Templar founded, to defend Holy Land
Catholic First Lateran Council
Holyrood Abbey in Scotland

event.title: Peter of Bruys burned at the stake

data.event: Peter of Bruys, burned at the stake
Tintern Abbey in Wales
Antipope Anacletus II
Catholic Second Lateran Council
Decretum Gratiani, Catholic Canon law
Peter Abélard, Letters of Abelard and Heloise
The Saint Denis Basilica of Abbot Suger is the first major building in the style of Gothic architecture.
Pope Adrian IV, first (and to date only) English pope

event.title: Theotokos of Vladimir arrives to Bogolyubovo

data.event: Theotokos of Vladimir arrives to Bogolyubovo
Carmelites founded

event.title: Notre Dame de Paris construction begins

data.event: Notre Dame de Paris, construction begun
Waldensians founded
Catholic Third Lateran Council
Teutonic Knights founded
Latin Empire of Constantinople

Saint Francis of Assisi becomes a hermit, founding the Franciscan order of friars, renounces wealth and begins his ministry; the Rosary is reportedly given to St. Dominic (who founded Dominican order) by an apparition of Mary
Catholic Fourth Lateran Council, decreed special dress for Jews and Muslims
St Alexander Nevsky, holy patron of Russia

event.title: Charter of University of Paris granted by pope

data.event: Charter of the University of Paris granted by Pope Gregory IX.
Catholic First Council of Lyon
Ad exstirpanda, Pope Innocent IV authorized use of torture in Inquisitions
Date which a 1988 Vatican sponsored scientific study places the origin of the Shroud of Turin
Summa Theologiae, written by Thomas Aquinas, theologian and philosopher, landmark systematic theology which later became official Catholic doctrine
Catholic Second Council of Lyon
Avignon Papacy, Popes reside in Avignon, France
Divine Comedy, by Dante Alighieri
Catholic Council of Vienne, disbanded Knights Templar

event.title: Last Grandmaster of Knights Templar burned at stake

data.event: Jacques de Molay, last Grandmaster of Knights Templar, burned at the stake
Metropolitan Peter moves his see from Kiev to Moscow
Orthodox Fifth Council of Constantinople
Marsilius of Padua
Sergii Radonezhskii founds a hermitage in the woods, which would grow into the Troitse-Sergiyeva Lavra
Black Death
Western Schism in Roman Catholicism

Wyclif's Bible, by John Wycliffe, eminent theologian at Oxford, NT in 1380, OT (with help of Nicholas of Hereford) in 1382, translations into Middle English, 1st complete translation to English, included deuterocanonical books, preached against abuses, expressed anti-catholic views of the sacraments (Penance and Eucharist), the use of relics, and Clerical celibacy

event.title: Translations of Scriptures into vernacular forbidden

data.event: Council of Oxford forbids translations of the Scriptures into the vernacular unless and until they were fully approved by Church authority

event.title: Gregory XII, Benedict XIII deposed, Alexander V elected

data.event: Council of Pisa, declared Roman Pope Gregory XII and Avignon Pope Benedict XIII deposed, elected Pope Alexander V (called the Pisan Pope)

Catholic Council of Constance, asked Gregory XII, Benedict XIII, Pisan Pope John XXIII to resign their papal claims, then elected Pope Martin V; condemned John Wycliffe and Jan Hus who was burned at the stake
Council of Siena
Catholic University of Leuven
Andrei Rublev, the greatest of medieval icon-painters

event.title: Joan of Arc burned at stake

data.event: St. Joan of Arc, French national heroine, burned at the stake
Catholic Council of Basel-Ferrara-Florence
Notre-Dame de Strasbourg, highest building in the world till 1874
Fall of Constantinople, overrun by Ottoman Empire
Gutenberg Bible, first printed Bible, by Johann Gutenberg
Sistine Chapel built
Spanish Inquisition established by Pope Sixtus IV
December 5, Summis desiderantes against Witchcraft issued by Pope Innocent VIII
Girolamo Savonarola, Dominican priest, Bonfire of the Vanities

event.title: Old St. Peter's Basilica torn down

data.event: Pope Julius II orders the Old St. Peter's Basilica torn down and authorizes Donato Bramante to plan a new structure, demolition completed in 1606
Vatican Swiss Guard founded
Michelangelo frescoes the Sistine Chapel's vaulted ceiling
Catholic Fifth Council of the Lateran, condemned Conciliarism
95 Theses of Martin Luther begins German Protestant Reformation
Diet of Worms condemns Luther
Ferdinand Magellan claims the Philippines for Spain, first mass and subsequent conversion to Catholicism, first in Asia
Luther's NT, German NT translation
Anabaptist movement begins

1526 Tyndale's NT, English NT translation from 1516 Greek text of Erasmus, first printed edition, used as a vehicle by Tyndale for bitter attacks on Catholicism, reflects influence of Luther's NT in rejecting priest for elder, church for congregation, banned in 1546 by Henry VIII
Augsburg Confession, Luther founds the Lutheran Church
Huldrych Zwingli, Protestant Reformation in Switzerland, independent of Luther

event.title: Our Lady of Guadalupe in Mexico

data.event: Our Lady of Guadalupe in Mexico
Henry VIII established independent Church of England
Jesuit order founded by Ignatius of Loyola, helped reconvert large areas of Poland, Hungary, and S. Germany and sent missionaries to the New World, India, and China

Myles Coverdale's Bible, used Tyndale's NT along with Latin and German versions, included Apocrypha at the end of the OT (like Luther's Bible of 1534) as was done in later English versions, 1537 edition received royal license, but banned in 1546 by Henry VIII
Thomas More refused to accept King Henry VIII's claim to be the supreme head of the Church in England, and was executed.
Desiderius Erasmus, Dutch scholar, Greek NT used in many 16th century translations
Tyndale put to death, left his OT translation in manuscript, English ecclesiastical authorities ordered his Bible burned because it was thought to be part of Lutheran reform
Institutes of the Christian Religion written by John Calvin (Calvinism)

event.title: John of Leiden, fanatic Dutch Anabaptist

data.event: John of Leiden, fanatic Dutch Anabaptist
Jacob Hutter founder of Hutterites
Helvetic Confessions of the Reformed Churches of Switzerland
Dissolution of the Monasteries in England, Wales and Ireland

event.title: Lutheranism state religion of Norway, Denmark

data.event: Christian III of Denmark decreed Lutheranism state religion of Norway and Denmark

Matthew Bible, by John Rogers, based on Tyndale and Coverdale received royal license but not authorized for use in public worship, numerous editions, 1551 edition contained offensive notes (based on Tyndale)
Michelangelo paints the Last Judgement

Great Bible, by Thomas Cromwell, 1st English Bible to be authorized for public use in English churches, defective in many places, based on last Tyndale's NT of 1534-1535, corrected by a Latin version of the Hebrew OT, Latin Bible of Erasmus, and Complutensian Polyglot, last edition 1569, never denounced by England
John Calvin returns to Geneva to establish a theocracy
Roman Inquisition established by Pope Paul III
Parliament of England bans Tyndale's translation as a "crafty, false and untrue translation"

event.title: Catholic Council of Trent defines biblical canon

data.event: Catholic Council of Trent, counter-reformation against Protestantism, clearly defined an official theology and biblical canon
Original Book of Common Prayer of the Church of England by Thomas Cranmer
The Stoglav Church Council (One Hundred Chapters) Moscow, Russia
Francis Xavier, Jesuit missionary, "Apostle of the Indies"
Pontifical Gregorian University founded at Vatican City
Michael Servetus founder of Unitarianism, burned at the stake in Geneva under Calvin
Queen Mary I of England, Bloody Mary, persecuted reformers: John Rogers, Hugh Latimer, Nicholas Ridley, Thomas Cranmer; of 238 burned at the stake
Military Order of the Golden Spur founded by Pope Paul IV

Geneva Bible, NT a revision of Matthew's version of Tyndale with use of Theodore Beza's NT (1556), OT a thorough revision of Great Bible, appointed to be read in Scotland (but not England), at least 140 editions, first Bible with chapter and verse numbers
Scots Confession, Church of Scotland, Scottish Reformation
French Wars of Religion
Goa Inquisition, persecution of Hindus and Jews in India, see also Christianity in India
Menno Simons founder of Mennonites

event.title: Thirty-Nine Articles of Church of England

data.event: Thirty-Nine Articles of Church of England, also decreed Biblical canon
Heidelberg Catechism of Reformed churches
Roman Catechism
Metropolitan Philip of Moscow strangled by Malyuta Skuratov
1572 John Knox, founded Scotch Presbyterian Church, due to disagreement with Lutherans over sacraments and church government
Bishops' Bible, a revision of the Great Bible checked against the Hebrew text, 1st to be published in England by episcopal authority

event.title: Our Lady of Kazan in Russia

data.event: Discovery of the holiest Russian icon, Our Lady of Kazan
Book of Concord of Lutheranism
St Terese of Avila
Gregorian calendar adopted at different times in different regions of the world
Toyotomi Hideyoshi expelled Jesuits from Kyushu

event.title: Jove elected first Patriarch of Moscow

data.event: Metropolitan Jove is elected the first Patriarch of Moscow
Sistine Vulgate, replaced by Pope Clement VIII's Clementine Vulgate in 1592, standard Latin Catholic Bible till 1960's
Michelangelo's dome in St Peter's Basilica completed
Ukrainian Catholic Church forms when Ukrainian subjects of the king of Poland are reunited with Rome, largest Byzantine Catholic Church
Giordano Bruno, Dominican priest, burned at the stake
Fausto Paolo Sozzini Socinianism

event.title: St Peter's Basilica redesigned into Latin cross

data.event: Carlo Maderno redesigns St Peter's Basilica into a Latin cross
Jamestown, Virginia founded
Baptist Church founded by John Smyth, due to objections to infant baptism and demands for church-state separation

event.title: Rheims-Douay Bible, first Catholic English translation

data.event: Rheims-Douay Bible, 1st Catholic English translation, OT published in two volumes, based on an unofficial Louvain text corrected by Sistine Vulgate, NT is Rheims text of 1582

King James Version (Authorised Version) is released, based primarily on Wycliffe's work & Bishop's Bible of 1572, translators are accused of being "damnable corrupters of God's word", original included Apocrypha
Fama Fraternitatis, Rosicrucian manifesto
Thirty Years' War
Plymouth Colony founded
Robert Bellarmine
Armand Jean du Plessis, Cardinal Richelieu
City upon a Hill, sermon by John Winthrop
Cornelius Jansen, bishop of Ypres, founder of Jansenism
Shimabara Rebellion
Anne Hutchinson banished as a heretic from Massachusetts

event.title: Mass. Bay Colony's social constitution established

data.event: John Cotton, advocate of theonomy, helps to establish the social constitution of the Massachusetts Bay Colony.
Acta Sanctorum
Long Parliament directed that only Hebrew canon be read in the Church of England (effectively removed the Apocrypha)

Westminster Standards produced by the Assembly, one of the first and undoubtedly the most important and lasting religious document drafted after the reconvention of the Parliament, also decreed Biblical canon
George Fox founds the Quaker movement
James Ussher, calculates date of creation as October 23, 4004 B.C.
Raskol of the Russian Orthodox Church
King Charles II of England, restoration of monarchy, continuing through James II, reversed decision of Long Parliament of 1644, reinstating the Apocrypha, reversal not heeded by non-conformists
Greek Orthodox Synod of Jerusalem, decreed Biblical canon
Philipp Jakob Spener publishes Pia Desideria, which becomes a manifesto for Pietism
John Bunyan publishes Pilgrim's Progress

event.title: Leader of Old Believers burned at stake

data.event: Avvakum, leader of the Old Believers, burned at the stake in the Far North of Russia
Roger Williams (theologian), advocate of Separation of church and state, founder of Providence, Rhode Island
Edict of Fontainebleau outlaws Protestantism in France
Orthodoxy introduced to Beijing by Russian Orthodox Church
Salem witch trials in Colonial America
Chinese Rites controversy
Jacob Amman founder of Amish

event.title: Old Catholic Church of Netherlands splits with Roman Catholicism

data.event: Old Catholic Church of the Netherlands splits with Roman Catholicism

event.title: Moscow Patriarchate substituted with Holy Synod

data.event: Peter the Great substituted Moscow Patriarchate with the Holy Synod
The Vicar of Bray (song)
First Great Awakening in U.S.
Welsh Methodist revival
Methodist movement, led by John Wesley and his hymn-writing brother Charles, begins

event.title: Sinners in the Hands of an Angry God

data.event: Sinners in the Hands of an Angry God, famous Fire and brimstone sermon

event.title: An Historical Account of Two Notable Corruptions of Scripture

data.event: An Historical Account of Two Notable Corruptions of Scripture, by Isaac Newton, published
Suppression of the Jesuits
New Smyrna, Florida, Greek Orthodox colony founded
Mission San Diego de Alcala, first California mission
Emanuel Swedenborg, founded Swedenborgianism

event.title: Ann Lee, leader of American Shakers

data.event: Ann Lee leader of American Shakers

event.title: The History of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire

data.event: Gibbon's The History of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire, critical of Christianity
Mission Delores, San Francisco
Virginia Statute for Religious Freedom, "Jesus never coerced anyone to follow him, and the imposition of a religion by government officials is impious"
Robert Raikes begins Sunday schools to reach poor and uneducated children in England
American Methodists form Methodist Episcopal Church at so-called "Christmas Conference", led by bishops Thomas Coke and Francis Asbury
John Carroll, Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Baltimore, first Roman Catholic US bishop
Dechristianisation of France during the French Revolution
First Amendment to the United States Constitution
Herman of Alaska brings Orthodoxy to Alaska
The Age of Reason written by Thomas Paine, advocated Deism
Treaty with Tripoli (1796), article 11: "the Government of the United States of America is not, in any sense, founded on the Christian religion"
Friedrich Schleiermacher publishes his first book, beginning Liberal Christianity movement
Cane Ridge, Kentucky
The Campbells begin Restoration Movement

event.title: Orthodox Christian martyred in San Francisco

data.event: Peter the Aleut, orthodox Christian tortured and martyred in Catholic San Francisco, California
Bishop Richard Allen, a former slave, founds the African Methodist Episcopal Church, the first African-American denomination
Thomas Jefferson produced the Jefferson Bible
English translation of Wilhelm Gesenius' ...Handwörterbuch...: Hebrew-English Lexicon, Hendrickson Publishers
Plymouth Brethren founded, Dispensationalism
Charles Finney's revivals lead to Second Great Awakening in America
April 6 Church of Christ (Mormonism) founded by Joseph Smith, Jr. as a result of reported visitations and commandment by God the Father, Jesus Christ, and later the Angel Moroni.
Church of Christ (Disciples) organized, made up of Presbyterians in distress over Protestant factionalism and decline of fervor
John Keble's sermon "National Apostasy" initiates the Oxford Movement in England
Saxon Lutherans objecting to the Prussian Union emigrate from Germany to the United States; settle in Perry County, Missouri. Leads to formation of the LC-MS
October 22 Great Disappointment, false prediction of Second Coming of Christ by Millerites
Southern Baptist Convention formed in Augusta, Georgia
1848 Epistle to the Easterns and Encyclical of the Eastern Patriarchs response
Perfectionist movement in western New York state

event.title: Missionary Hudson Taylor arrives in China

data.event: Missionary Hudson Taylor arrives in China

event.title: Immaculate Conception defined as Catholic dogma

data.event: 1854 Immaculate Conception, defined as Catholic dogma
Søren Kierkegaard, founder of Christian existentialism
September 11 Mormons, led by John D. Lee, massacre 120 Christian settlers at Mountain Meadows, Utah
Methodist preacher William Booth founds the Salvation Army, vowing to bring the gospel into the streets to the most desperate and needy
Catholic First Vatican Council, asserted doctrine of Papal Infallibility, rejected by Christian Catholic Church of Switzerland

event.title: Italy declares war on Papal States

data.event: Italy declared war on the Papal States. The Italian Army enters Rome. Papal States ceased to exist.
German Kulturkampf against Roman Catholicism
Church of Christ, Scientist founded in Boston by Mary Baker Eddy

Revised Version, called for by Church of England, used Greek based on Septuagint (B) and (S), Hebrew Masoretic Text used in OT, follows Greek order of words, greater accuracy than AV, includes Apocrypha, scholarship never disputed
Charles Taze Russell founded Bible Student movement
Baltimore Catechism
Moody Bible Institute
The Kingdom of God is Within You, by Leo Tolstoy, start of Christian anarchism
Christian flag, conceived in Brooklyn, New York
Gideons International founded

event.title: French law on separation of Church and State

data.event: 1905 French law on the separation of Church and State

event.title: The Quest of the Historical Jesus

data.event: Albert Schweitzer publishes The Quest of the Historical Jesus (English translation 1910)
Biblia Hebraica
Azusa Street Revival in Los Angeles, CA begins modern Pentecostal movement
Nikolai of Japan, Archbishop of Japanese Orthodox Church
Scofield Reference Bible
Edinburgh Missionary Conference launches modern missions movement and modern ecumenical movement; 5-point statement of the Presbyterian General Assembly, also used by Fundamentalists
The Fundamentals, a 12-volume collection of essays by 64 British and American scholars and preachers, a foundation of Fundamentalism
Catholic Encyclopedia
Welsh Church Act 1914
Iglesia ni Cristo incorporated in the Philippines
Armenian Genocide
Father Divine founded International Peace Mission movement

event.title: And did those feet in ancient time

data.event: And did those feet in ancient time
Restitution of the Moscow Patriarchy with Tikhon as patriarch

event.title: True Jesus Church founded in Beijing

data.event: True Jesus Church founded in Beijing

event.title: Execution of Holy Martyrs of Russia

data.event: Execution of Holy Martyrs of Russia, including the last tsar, Nicholas II, and his wife, Alexandra Feodorovna
Karl Barth's Commentary on Romans is published, critiquing Liberal Christianity and beginning the neo-orthodox movement
Oxford Group founded at Oxford
Aimee Semple McPherson built Angelus Temple
Scopes Trial, caused division among Fundamentalists
United Church of Canada formed
Father Charles Coughlin's first radio broadcast
Pope Pius XI decrees Comma Johanneum open to dispute

event.title: Lateran Treaty between Italy and Papacy

data.event: Lateran Treaty signed containing three agreements between kingdom of Italy and the papacy.
Rastafari movement founded on visit of Haile Selassie to Jamaica
Jehovah's Witnesses founded
Christ the Redeemer (statue) in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil
Catholic Worker Movement founded
Herbert W. Armstrong founded Radio Church of God
Dr. Frank C. Laubach, known as "The Apostle to the Illiterates." working in the Philippines, developed a literacy program that continues to teach millions of people to read.

event.title: Critical edition of Koine Greek Septuagint

data.event: Rahlf's critical edition of the Koine Greek Septuagint
Billy Sunday, early U.S. radio evangelist
Southern and Northern US branches of the Methodist Episcopal Church, along with the Methodist Protestant Church reunite to form The Methodist Church. Slavery had divided the church in the 1800s.
Monumento Nacional de Santa Cruz del Valle de los Caidos, world's largest cross, 152.4 meters high
Roman Catholic sex abuse cases begins
Dietrich Bonhoeffer is executed by the Nazis
Ludwig Müller
Revised Standard Version, revision of AV "based on consonantal Hebrew text" for OT and best available texts for NT, done in response to changes in English usage
Uneasy Conscience of Modern Fundamentalism by Carl F. H. Henry, a landmark of Evangelicalism versus Fundamentalism in US
Oral Roberts founded Evangelistic Association
Dead Sea scrolls discovered
1948 World Council of Churches is founded
Declaration of the Establishment of the State of Israel, see also Christian Zionism

event.title: Billy Graham preaches his first crusade

data.event: Evangelist Billy Graham preaches his first Los Angeles crusade
Assumption of Mary decreed by Pope Pius XII

The Last Temptation a fictional account of the life of Jesus writen by Nikos Kazantzakis, wherin Christ's divinity is juxtaposed with his humanity, is published, and promptly banned in many countries.
Novum Testamentum Graece, critical edition of Greek NT, basis of modern translations
Unification Church founded
U.S. Pledge of Allegiance modified by act of Congress from "one nation, indivisible" to "one nation, under God, indivisible"

event.title: In God We Trust national motto

data.event: In God We Trust designated U.S. national motto
Anchor Bible Series
The Ten Commandments (1956 film)
United Church of Christ founded by ecumenical union of Congregationalists and Evangelical & Reformed, representing Calvinists and Lutherans
English translation of Walter Bauer's Wörterbuch ...: A Greek-English Lexicon of the New Testament and Other Early Christian Literature, University of Chicago Press
Family Radio founded

Catholic Second Vatican Council, announced by Pope John XXIII in 1959, produced 16 documents which became official Roman Catholic teaching after approval by the Pope, purpose to renew "ourselves and the flocks committed to us"
Martin Luther King leads a civil rights march in Washington, D.C.
C. S. Lewis dies November 22.

event.title: Bible reading prohibited in US public schools

data.event: Campaign by Madalyn Murray O'Hair results in U.S. Supreme Court ruling prohibiting reading of Bible in public schools
Rousas John Rushdoony founds Chalcedon Foundation
United Methodist Church formed with union of Methodist Church & Evangelical United Brethren Church, becoming the largest Methodist/Wesleyan church in the world
Mass of Paul VI replaces Tridentine Mass
The Late, Great Planet Earth futurist book by Hal Lindsey
Chick Publications
New American Standard Bible
The Exorcist, a novel of demonic possession and the mysteries of the Catholic faith, is published.
Jim Bakker founds PTL television ministry

event.title: Metzger's commentary on Greek New Testament

data.event: Bruce Metzger's Textual Commentary on the Greek New Testament
Anneliese Michel, Bavarian woman, underwent exorcism against demon possession
New Perspective on Paul
New International Version of the Bible is first published (revised in 1984), using a variety of Greek texts, Masoretic Hebrew texts, and current English style
Pope John Paul II, reaffirmed conservative moral traditions (The Splendor of Truth) and the forbidding of women in the priesthood
Moral Majority founded by Jerry Falwell
New King James Version, complete revision of 1611 AV, updates archaisms while retaining style
Jesus Seminar founded
Jesus and Judaism published by E. P. Sanders, won Grawemeyer Prize for best religious book of the 80's
Christian Coalition

event.title: The Last Tempation of Christ movie

data.event: The Last Temptation of Christ, directed by Martin Scorsese, is released by Universal Pictures, and promptly attacked as heretical by organized Christian and Catholic groups. Boycotts are launched, violence ensues at some showings of the film in France.
New Revised Standard Version
Catechism of the Catholic Church
Declaration of cooperation between Evangelicals and Catholics
Porvoo Communion
Answers In Genesis founded by Ken Ham.
Mother Teresa died
Raymond E. Brown, Catholic scholar, died
The Way of the Master founded
Dan Brown writes The Da Vinci Code, criticized because of historical inaccuracy of the life of Jesus.
Mel Gibson's film The Passion of the Christ is released
Death of Pope John Paul II, election of Pope Benedict XVI
Abdul Rahman (convert)
Gospel of Judas discovered
